cliftonccraig wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
>  > Yes. Since it's just a stub, it's set up simply to return your value.
>  >
> That's what I thought.
> 
>  > Invoke verify() at the end of the your test /and/ set the
> expectation to
>  > "at least five calls" and not "at least once", as you're doing now. (I
>  > don't know the precise syntax.)
>  >
> 
> That's what I need. I need the precise syntax to enforce a given
> number of invocations. There is no atLeastNumTimes() method that I can
> find to enforce this. I only see once() and atleastOnce() methods.
>  > So change what you pass to expects(), then be sure to invoke
> verify() at
>  > the end of the test.
> 
> Interestingly I haven't had the need to invoke verify at the end of my
> tests. I know it's good practice but it appears as though JMock gives
> immediate verification.

It does, but only if something unexpected happens, and not if the 
something expected doesn't happen. So the 6th invocation fails fast, but 
not the missing 5th.

 > Anyhows, what I really need is a good example
> of how to setup an expectation for a given number of invocations on a
> single method. I also want to incorporate different return values for
> each invocation. In essence what I'm mocking is a custom interator.
> Could someone give me a good how-to on this?

Let's see...

It looks like you can use exactly().

blah.expect(exactly(5))....

Have you tried that yet?
